column3: U-433 (Oblt. Hans Ey). Sunk at 2155hrs on 16 November 1941 in the Mediterranean Sea east of Gibraltar

column3: U-133 (Kptlt. Eberhard Mohr). Sunk on 14 March 1942 in the Mediterranean Sea south of Salamis

column3: U-573 (Kptlt. Heinrich Heinsohn). Badly damaged on 1 May 1942 in the Mediterranean Sea north-west of Ténès
column6: by depth charges from a British Hudson aircraft (233 Sqn RAF/M).

column3: U-74 (Oblt. Karl Friederich). Sunk on 2 May 1942 in the Mediterranean east-southeast of Cartagena

column3: U-568 (Kptlt. Joachim Preuss). Sunk at 0500hrs on 28 May 1942 in the Mediterranean Sea north-east of Tobruk

column7: after being located by a British Blenheim aircraft (203 Sqn RAF/S).

column6: by depth charges from the British destroyers HMS Pakenham

column6:
by depth charges from two British Hudson aircraft (608 Sqn RAF/C & D).

Beached and blown up by its crew later that day off Cape Khamis
column7: in position 36.16N
column9: after further air attacks by five British Hudson aircraft (500 Sqn RAF/F

column3: U-605 (Kptlt. Herbert-Viktor Schütze). Sunk on 14 November 1942 in the Mediterranean Sea north-west of Oran

column6: by a torpedo from a British Albacore aircraft (820 Sqn FAA) and strafing by two British Martlet aircraft (893 Sqn FAA) from the British aircraft carrier HMS Formidable
column7: after being badly damaged by depth charges and strafing from three British Hudson aircraft (500 Sqn RAF/C

column3: U-224 (Oblt. Hans-Karl Kosbadt). Sunk on 13 January 1943 in the Mediterranean Sea west of Algiers

column3: U-301 (Kptlt. Willy-Roderich Körner). Sunk on 21 January 1943 in the Mediterranean Sea west of Bonifacio
column6: 07.04E by torpedoes from the British submarine HMS Sahib.

column6: by depth charges from the British destroyer HMS Paladin
column7:
assisted by a South African Bisley aircraft (15 Sqn SAAF/W).

Captured by a boarding party of the destroyer that seized several confidential books and documents. U-205 foundered a few hours later while under tow by the British corvette HMS Gloxinia off Ras al Hilal in position 32.54

column3: U-83 (Kptlt. Ulrich Wörisshoffer). Sunk on 4 March 1943 in the Mediterranean south-east of Cartagena

column7: 00.10E on 28 March.

column3: U-602 (Kptlt. Philipp Schüler). Missing since 19 April 1943 in the Mediterranean Sea north of Oran. There is no explanation for its loss.

column6: by a torpedo from the British submarine HMS Sickle.

column3: U-375 (Kptlt. Jürgen Koenenkamp). Missing since 25 July 1943 in the Mediterranean Sea south of Sicily. There is no explanation for its loss.

column7: by depth charges from the British escort destroyer HMS Easton and the Greek escort destroyer Pindos.

column6:
by depth charges from two British Wellington aircraft (179 Sqn RAF/P & J).

Beached west of Cape Tres Forcas
column7: in position 35.13N
column8: 03.21W. The wreck was subsequently attacked by British Hudson aircraft (48 and 233 Sqn RAF) and two British Swordfish aircraft (833 and 886 Sqn FAA) and finally destroyed by gunfire from the British corvette HMS Hyacinth and the Australian minesweeper HMAS Wollongong.

column3: U-431 (Oblt. Dietrich Schöneboom). Sunk on 21 October 1943 in the Mediterranean Sea east of Cartagena

column8: the British destroyers HMS Active and HMS Witherington and a British Wellington aircraft (179 Sqn RAF/R).

column3: U-73 (Oblt. Horst Deckert). Sunk on 16 December 1943 in the Mediterranean north of Oran
column6: by depth charges and gunfire from the US destroyers USS Woolsey and USS Trippe.

column7: by bombs during US air raid (15th AF).

column7:
by bombs during US air raid (15th AF).

The wreck was raised
column8: taken to Missiessy Dock No. 2 and broken up in 1946.

column7:
by bombs during a US air raid (15th AF). No casualties.

Wreck raised on 12 April 1945 and broken up in 1946.

column3: U-952 (Kptlt. Oskar Curio). Badly damaged on 5 July 1944 in Missiessy Dock No. 3 at Toulon
column5:
by bombs during US air raid (15th AF).

column3: U-967 (). Scuttled on 19 August 1944 off Saint-Mandrier peninsula at Toulon
column7: to prevent capture because the boat was unseaworthy after being badly damaged by bombs during US air raids (15th AF) at Toulon on 5 July

column3: U-407 (Oblt. Hans Kolbus). Sunk on 19 September 1944 in the Mediterranean Sea south of Milos

column3: U-596 (). Scuttled on 30 September 1944 in the Skaramanga Bay
column6: after being badly damaged by bombs during a US air raid (15th AF) in Salamis on 24 September 1944.

column3: U-565 (Kptlt. Fritz Henning). Scuttled on 30 September 1944 with three depth charges in the Skaramanga Bay
